transcripts.text: People listened to you in New Hampshire and said you were the candidate that understood boys' issues better than any other candidate.  I'm so glad.  He was very impressed.  Can you share a little bit with me about what your passion is for the issues of boys?

I have two young boys myself, and I think that, for whatever reason, our culture is is ignoring the fact that we have so many young men in particular who feel like they're getting pushed to the sidelines in schools, schools aren't designed for them, and they get on the workforce that the workforce doesn't have a place for them.  And then for whatever reason, it's all being blamed on the individual.  Really, we have a systemic transformation of our economy.  And schools that don't really meet the needs of a lot of boys in particular, because they emphasize conformity and rigidity, And at that age, like a lot of boys, you know, like aren't really well designed for that in the same way that young girls are, frankly.  And so we need to start addressing these issues from the ground up.  Hey, how are you?  And it starts, I mean, to me, it's beyond our schools at this point because there are so many young men, almost one out of, five prime working age American men is out of the workforce.  And again, it all gets laid at their feet like it's all their fault.  But in my mind, it's structural.  And it's giving rise to all of these dysfunctions in families, in communities.  There are a lot of men that feel like they're not going to ever get married, have a family, have a stable career, and everything else.  And for whatever reason, we're ignoring what strikes me as a real crisis.
I did 14 years of research on this and looking at the various causes, and one of the things I found to be the prime cause is dad deprivation, where boys do not have dads.

40% of kids are born to single parents today, and 90% of those cases are single moms.  So if you're a little boy growing up with a single mom, your mom's generally working, you don't have enough time, and you don't have strong male role models, and it's like a cascading effect.
